item.title: Covid-19: Boris Johnson to unveil 'cautious' plan to lift England's lockdown
item.description: All schools are expected to reopen on 8 March, with some outdoor socialising allowed from 29 March.

item.title: Airlines ground Boeing 777s after Denver engine failure
item.description: United Airlines, Korean Air and Japan's two main airlines suspend dozens of the jets from use.

item.title: 'They wanted to jail a banker - I was that banker'
item.description: Tom Hayes, jailed for rigging interest rates, tells the BBC fresh evidence will show his conviction was unsafe.

item.title: Covid-19: PM to announce lockdown exit plan, and Scottish and Welsh schools start to reopen
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday morning.

item.title: Fly-tipping: Licensing system failing to stop dumping, Panorama finds
item.description: A BBC Panorama investigation finds licensed firms involved in the dumping of rubbish.

item.title: Edvard Munch wrote 'madman' graffiti on Scream painting, scans show
item.description: The words "Can only have been painted by a madman" are written in the corner of the famous painting.

item.title: More than half of UK employers planning to recruit staff
item.description: The number of firms planning to make staff redundant in the first quarter of 2021 is also falling.

item.title: Covid: Australian Open fans criticised for 'booing vaccine'
item.description: A crowd's booing of a reference to Covid-19 vaccines is "disgusting", Australia's deputy PM says.

item.title: Bitcoin keeps hitting new highs after Tesla backing
item.description: Having broken through the $50,000 level last week the cryptocurrency has extended its rally this year.

item.title: Covid: Catch-up narrative putting 'huge pressure' on children, psychologists say
item.description: The British Psychological Society warns against reinforcing the notion that school pupils are "behind".

item.title: Texas weather: State should pay soaring power bills, says Houston mayor
item.description: Many residents who managed to keep their power on now face electricity bills of thousands of dollars.

item.title: China 'Sexy tea' shop apologises for calling women 'bargains'
item.description: The popular beverage chain had previously sold tea bags with the phrase "Master I want you".

item.title: The Papers: 'March to freedom' and 'return to the great outdoors'
item.description: Monday's papers are dominated by the prime minister's plan to ease lockdown in England.

item.title: Covid and PTSD: Dispelling misconceptions on those who may have it and why
item.description: Lifting the lid on common misconceptions, a mother and former Facebook moderator share their experience with post traumatic stress disorder.

item.title: The Walking Dead cast on the final season of a global hit
item.description: The Walking Dead is back for a new season - but it's also the show's last.

item.title: Divya Kakran: 'I became famous for wrestling boys'
item.description: Divya Kakran, a young Indian wrestler, dreams of making history at the Olympics.

item.title: Jasmine Harrison on being youngest solo female to row Atlantic Ocean
item.description: Jasmine Harrison, 21, on becoming the youngest woman to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: The homemade special effects livening up lockdown
item.description: Peter Quinn moved from Northern Ireland to America to work in the VFX industry over a decade ago.

item.title: Kangaroo Island dunnart: Saving a bushfire-ravaged marsupial
item.description: Already critically endangered, Australia's Kangaroo Island dunnart has lost most of its habitat.

item.title: Mask force: London's five centuries of face coverings
item.description: Not a new normal: A brief history of five centuries of face masks.

item.title: Lockdown review: What are the risks of schools, pubs and shops reopening?
item.description: Lockdown could slowly be lifted soon but what are the risks associated with relaxing certain restrictions?

item.title: Africa's data gap: Measuring the cost of not counting the dead
item.description: Just eight countries in Africa have adequate death registration systems, a BBC investigation finds.

item.title: The video call apps linking home workers with strangers
item.description: A number of tech firms are connecting people working from home with strangers via video calls.

item.title: 'Coins can inspire people to look into the past'
item.description: BBC News website readers share their old coin collections and the stories behind them.

item.title: Over-The-Rhine: Is this a model for urban renewal or a warning sign?
item.description: In Cincinnati's Over-The-Rhine neighbourhood, does urban revitalisation come at a cost?

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Don't ask me which vaccine is best, please
item.description: Dr John Wright says he's often asked which vaccine is best, but the answer is it's too early to say.

item.title: Spurs have problems 'I cannot resolve' but are not in crisis - Mourinho
item.description: Tottenham manager Jose Mourinho says Spurs "have problems I cannot resolve" but insists they are not in crisis after losing to West Ham.

item.title: Which way will the 'GOAT race' go after Djokovic narrows the gap?
item.description: Not only was Novak Djokovic playing for the Australian Open title on Sunday, he was jostling for position in the race to be crowned the 'GOAT' in men's tennis.

item.title: Rashford helps Man Utd back to second with win against struggling Newcastle
item.description: Marcus Rashford plays a key role in a win over struggling Newcastle as Manchester United returned to second in the Premier League table.

item.title: World number 81 Brown beats O'Sullivan to win Welsh Open
item.description: World number 81 Jordan Brown beats Ronnie O'Sullivan 9-8 in a final-frame decider to win the 2021 Welsh Open.

item.title: Who shone as a lone striker? Read Garth Crooks' team of the week
item.description: Who was immense in defence? Which midfielder is rejuvenating his career? Find out in Garth Crooks' team of the week.

item.title: Watch the bizarre moment referee Oscar Macias accidentally blocks an effort on goal
item.description: Watch the bizarre moment referee Oscar Macias accidentally blocks an effort on goal from Cruz Azul in their Mexican league match against Toluca.

item.title: How many cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What are the UK's lockdown rules and when will they end?
item.description: People across the country have been urged to "double down" and stick to the lockdown rules.

item.title: Covid: When will schools reopen?
item.description: Boris Johnson is expected to focus on the re-opening of schools is his "roadmap" for easing lockdown.

item.title: How can children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: More people have been added to the clinically extremely vulnerable list in England. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Has the NHS got enough of the right PPE?
item.description: Who needs it - and does the UK health service have the right kit?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 16 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK, so when might you get one?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Is the Covid vaccine safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Vaccine passports: Do I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The growing number of people vaccinated may be able to gain more freedoms in the future.

item.title: Covax: How will Covid vaccines be shared around the world?
item.description: A scheme to distribute Covid-19 vaccines globally is under way. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of a new variant of Covid-19.

item.title: What is a challenge trial and why do we need them?
item.description: Some volunteers in the UK will be deliberately infected with coronavirus in a "challenge trial".

item.title: Covid: Claims vaccinations harm fertility unfounded
item.description: Social-media posts - some described as "scare stories" - are based on misunderstandings, experts say.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Covid: How will we know if the vaccine is working?
item.description: Deaths are falling faster for the over-80s - but does that mean the vaccine is working?

item.title: How Norway is offering drug-free treatment to people with psychosis
item.description: People with psychosis are usually given powerful medication - in Norway they can now choose to go drug-free.
